In this paper, we find it most convenient to view the fibre of a general W$^*$-bundle at $x \in X$ as the quotient ${\mathcal{M}}/I_x$, which we denote ${\mathcal{M}}_x$. We write $\tau_x$ for the induced faithful trace on this quotient and we write $a \mapsto a(x)$ for the canonical quotient map ${\mathcal{M}} \rightarrow {\mathcal{M}}_x$. Note that if $f \in C(X) \subseteq {\mathcal{M}}$, then $f - f(x)1_{{\mathcal{M}}} \in I_x$, so the image of $f$ in ${\mathcal{M}}_x$ is $f(x)1_{{\mathcal{M}}_x}$. This justifies the notation.

where the horizontal maps are the quotient maps, commutes. A diagram chase shows that $E_Y$ is a conditional expectation onto $C(X) / C_0(X \setminus Y) \subseteq {\mathcal{M}}_Y$.

To show that $E_Y(b_1b_2) = E_Y(b_2b_1)$ for all $b_1,b_2 \in {\mathcal{M}}_Y$, we take lifts $a_1, a_2 \in {\mathcal{M}}$ of $b_1,b_2$ respectively, note that $E(a_1a_2) = E(a_2a_1)$ and use the commuting digram above.

Suppose $E_Y(b^*b) = 0$ for some $b \in {\mathcal{M}}_Y$. Let $a \in {\mathcal{M}}$ be a lift of $b$. Then, by a diagram chase, $E(a^*a) \in C_0(X \setminus Y)$ and so $a \in I_Y$. Hence $b = 0$ in ${\mathcal{M}}_Y$.

All that remains is to prove that the unit ball of ${\mathcal{M}}_Y$ is complete in the uniform 2-norm. For this we shall need to pass to fibres. Write $a \mapsto a|_Y$ for the canonical map ${\mathcal{M}} \rightarrow {\mathcal{M}}_Y$. Let $y \in Y$. Since $I_Y \subseteq I_y$, the fibre map $a \mapsto a(y)$ factors through the restriction map $a \mapsto a|_Y$, and we have a commuting diagram for the central embeddings

	This proves that $\mathcal{B}$ does form the basis for a topology on $B$, and also gives the required neighbourhood basis for $b \in B$. 
	
(b) We check the axioms in turn. (i) Let $U$ be open in $X$. Let $b \in p^{-1}(U)$ with $x = p(b)$. Choose $a \in {\mathcal{M}}$ with $a(x) = b$. Then $b \in V(a, 1, U) \subseteq p^{-1}(U)$. So $p^{-1}(U)$ is open in $B$. So $p$ is continuous. 

Let $W$ be open in $B$ with $W \cap B|_{\leq 1} \neq \emptyset$. Let $x \in p(W \cap B|_{\leq 1})$. Choose $b \in W \cap B|_{\leq 1}$ such that $p(b) = x$. Lift $b \in {\mathcal{M}}_x$ to an element $a \in {\mathcal{M}}$ of the same norm. The open set $W$ contains a basic open neighbourhood of the form $V(a, \epsilon, U)$, where $\epsilon > 0$ and $U$ is a neighbourhood of $x$ in $X$. Hence, for all $x' \in U$, $a(x') \in W$ and $\|a(x')\|_{{\mathcal{M}}_{x'}} \leq 1$. Therefore $U \subseteq p(W \cap B|_{\leq 1})$ and so $p|_{B_{\leq 1}}: B_{\leq 1} \rightarrow X$ is open.

(ii) This follows from the fact that a basic open neighbourhood of $0_x$ has the form $V(0,\epsilon, U)$ for some $\epsilon > 0$ and some open neighbourhood $U$ of $x$ in $X$.

A basic neighbourhood of $\lambda b$ has the form $V(\lambda a, \epsilon, U)$ for some $\epsilon > 0$ and some open neighbourhood $U$ of $x$ in $B$. Set $K = \max(\|a\|_{2,u}, |\lambda|) + 1$ and $\delta = \min(\tfrac{\epsilon}{2K},1)$. Let $|\lambda' - \lambda| < \delta$ and $b' \in V(a, \delta, U)$ with $x' = p(b')$. Then
prevtext:
So, $b' \in V(a_i, \epsilon_i, U_i)$. Hence, $b \in V(a, \epsilon, U) \subseteq V(a_1, \epsilon_1, U_1) \cap V(a_2, \epsilon_2, U_2)$. 

	This proves that $\mathcal{B}$ does form the basis for a topology on $B$, and also gives the required neighbourhood basis for $b \in B$. 
	
(b) We check the axioms in turn. (i) Let $U$ be open in $X$. Let $b \in p^{-1}(U)$ with $x = p(b)$. Choose $a \in {\mathcal{M}}$ with $a(x) = b$. Then $b \in V(a, 1, U) \subseteq p^{-1}(U)$. So $p^{-1}(U)$ is open in $B$. So $p$ is continuous. 

Let $W$ be open in $B$ with $W \cap B|_{\leq 1} \neq \emptyset$. Let $x \in p(W \cap B|_{\leq 1})$. Choose $b \in W \cap B|_{\leq 1}$ such that $p(b) = x$. Lift $b \in {\mathcal{M}}_x$ to an element $a \in {\mathcal{M}}$ of the same norm. The open set $W$ contains a basic open neighbourhood of the form $V(a, \epsilon, U)$, where $\epsilon > 0$ and $U$ is a neighbourhood of $x$ in $X$. Hence, for all $x' \in U$, $a(x') \in W$ and $\|a(x')\|_{{\mathcal{M}}_{x'}} \leq 1$. Therefore $U \subseteq p(W \cap B|_{\leq 1})$ and so $p|_{B_{\leq 1}}: B_{\leq 1} \rightarrow X$ is open.

(ii) This follows from the fact that a basic open neighbourhood of $0_x$ has the form $V(0,\epsilon, U)$ for some $\epsilon > 0$ and some open neighbourhood $U$ of $x$ in $X$.

(iii) Continuity of addition follows from the observation

\]

that is, take the product ${\mathbb{R}} \times M$ modulo the equivalence relation $(t + n, m) \sim (t, \alpha(n)(m))$ for all $n \in {\mathbb{Z}}$. Together with the canonical quotient map $B \to S^1$, this is a topological bundle of tracial von Neumann algebras over $S^1$ in the sense of Definition \ref{def:top_bundle} with trivialising neighbourhoods as in (\ref{TrivialisingNhoods}). We can, therefore, via Theorem \ref{TheOtherOne}, define a locally trivial W$^*$-bundle ${\mathcal{M}}$ which induces $B$.

\begin{lem} 
Let $G$ be a finite group, let $M$ be the II$_1$-factor with ${{\rm Out}({M})} \cong G$ constructed above, let $\alpha \in {{\rm Aut}({M})}$ and $g = \theta(\alpha)$, such that $g \neq e$. Then the W$^*$-bundle ${\mathcal{M}}$ associated to the topological bundle $B$ given by (\ref{eqn:B}) is non-trivial.
\end{lem}

\begin{proof}
Let $q \colon P \to S^1$ be the principal ${{\rm Aut}({M})}$-bundle of $B$. Suppose for the sake of contradiction that ${\mathcal{M}}$ is trivialisable. By the results of Section~3, $P$ is trivialisable. Consider $Q = P \times_{\theta} G$ defined as the quotient of the product $P \times G$ with respect to the equivalence relation $(p \cdot\beta, g) \sim (p, \theta(\beta)\cdot g)$ for $\beta \in {{\rm Aut}({M})}$. If $P$ is trivialisable, so is $Q$, but $Q \to S^1$ is a principal $G$-bundle over $S^1$ for the finite group $G$. By elementary covering space theory the isomorphism classes of these are in correspondence with the conjugacy classes of $G$. But the bundle $Q$ corresponds to the class of $g \in G$, whereas the trivial bundle corresponds to the class of $e \in G$ in contradiction with $g \neq e$, therefore ${\mathcal{M}}$ can not be trivial.
\end{proof}

\begin{rem}
The above construction can easily be extended to non-trivial locally trivial W$^*$-bundles over more general spaces than $S^1$. Let $G$ be a finite group, let $X$ be a compact Hausdorff space, such that there exists a non-trivial principal $G$-bundle $\overline{X} \to X$. Since $G$ is discrete, $\overline{X}$ is just a covering space of $X$. Let $M$ be the II$_1$-factor constructed above. In particular, we have an isomorphism $\varphi \colon G \to {{\rm Out}({M})}$. There is an obstruction to lifting the $\varphi$ to a homomorphism $\hat{\varphi} \colon G \to {{\rm Aut}({M})}$, which lives in $H^3(G, \mathcal{U}(1))$. By \cite[Theorem 4.1.3]{Su80} it is the only obstruction. Suppose it vanishes, then the topological bundle
\(
	B = \overline{X} \times_{\hat{\varphi}} M
\) 
is non-trivial. In fact, let $P$ be the associated principal ${{\rm Aut}({M})}$-bundle and denote by $\theta \colon {{\rm Aut}({M})} \to G$ the quotient map. By construction we have an isomorphism 
\(
	\overline{X} \cong P \times_{\theta} G
\) 
of principal $G$-bundles. Since $\overline{X}$ was supposed to be non-trivial, the same holds true for $P$. Thus, the associated W$^*$-bundle is also non-trivial.
\end{rem}
